When this game launched, i excitedly flung myself into it and immersed myself. A beautiful game, with an excellent tactical gameplay loop which hooked me! I was addicted... Which brings me to my 2 issues. The game's runs are simply too long to FEEL like a roguelike, instead it feels like i'm playing through an incredibly long story segment out of a larger story, only to lose later on and be forced to repeat that. This was my first major qualm. As for my second, it would definitely be that upgrades feel... Near meaningless. I can't CC bosses, so some of them are relatively useless for boss fights, i can't 1 shot most enemies despite heavily focusing on 1 character, so it feels like the upgrades are simply a means to an end. When i have 4-5 Red skills and upgrades on a character, i hope for a frankly broken, absurd build to be formed. Instead, what i end up with, is a character with an extra skill that i will very seldom choose to use, and it just feels a bit underwhelming to get the rarest upgrades. 

As of writing this review and getting this all out, the Devs have stated they're working on these 2 issues, and i'm so SO excited to see what they do to improve this, as i truly ADORE this game, it oozes personality, and it's the perfect thing to tide me over, especially if they do manage to reduce run times. It's extremely refreshing to see devs listen to criticism and seek to improve the faults within their games, and i'm so very excited to see what they do going forward.

If you want to try a tactical rpg in a fantasy setting but have been turned off of modern Fire Emblem aesthetics and the 50+ hour runtime of the original Lost Eidolons, this might be a good option to try the genre. I would have loved to see more buildcraft which is something the Main game did very well. The game also has a cheap or budget feel to it that wasn't present in the original. I'd recommend waiting for a sale to grab it for 10-15$.

I want to start off by saying that I really enjoyed this game. It plays similarly to the first game, but you unlock skills as you go similar to Hades. You lose those skills when you die but keep some things to create upgrades for your next expeditions such as improved weapon strength. I love the skills and relics that are unlocked as you progress, as they are pretty unique for the genre.  However, it is a little deflating to start a new run without some of the skills that you get used to using. Seeing that a full run, can take over six hours, you get attached to some of the skills you collect. I feel like what is accomplished in a run is not rewarded quite as much as I would like. Having to start basically from square one is a little annoying. To be fair, that is standard with roguelikes, so the game is as advertised.

It is more combat focused, but there is a story that ties in really well to the first game which I found enjoyable.  There is a good variety of maps and objectives. The boss battles are challenging but fair.  The undo mechanic is helpful as one mistake that could end an entire run can  be undone. Voice acting is good and the characters are well-written. 

What did leave me deflated is that it ends after Chapter 3 with credits. Then it reveals a Chapter 4, but it makes me start back at the beginning to play through again. I felt like I was really starting to get invested in the game, and then it just cuts off. I understand that they want you to go through again, but being cut off like that was really annoying.

All of this being said,  I really enjoyed my time with it. I hope they take a lot of the mechanics from this game and implement them in a new Lost Eidolons game that is not a roguelike. I highly recommend this game if you enjoy Fire Emblem-like games but would prefer less of an anime aesthetic and a more mature plot. However, I would temper my expectations based on the length of the game. To be fair, I think it is priced accordingly.

Runs get fairly interesting once accessories are unlocked, but you have to beat the game once for those to unlock and then do successive runs on higher difficulties to gather materials to craft and upgrade them. I wish those had been unlocked from the beginning and were easier to collect materials for, as they add a fun spin to runs with the various abilities they provide. 

Overall, there's a decent amount of content here. Of course, it's nowhere near the level of other roguelite legends, but it's an enjoyable game for what it's priced at. I'm curious to know where else this franchise goes, now that the developer have waded into the roguelite waters. This is a pretty impressive first attempt at the genre.

This solid tactical RPG blends together features from fan favorites in the genre, with gameplay in the style of Fire Emblem, mission structure modeled after Darkest Dungeon 2, and upgrade/story progression borrowed from Hades. 

The standards of the genre apply here, including re-playable missions with variations to keep them feeling fresh, and various challenge modes you can enable to increase the difficulty for more rewards. The roster of playable characters also means that your party composition can change in different runs, creating a very different feel and different strategy for every group. Whether you want to lean heavily into magic, or brawling, or stealth, or range, is all up to you - or you can just grab one of each and see how it plays out.

The narrative borrows from Hades, in the sense that when you die and fail a run, the game doesn't just end and start over. The death is canon, and you get revived to try again, and your character is aware that he keeps dying and trying.

The voiceover work is surprisingly competent, despite featuring mostly lesser known names. The script, however, does sound oddly modern for a fantasy game. It works here thanks to a mostly straight-faced delivery, but if you are expecting some shakespearean style of medieval talk, it isn't here. These characters sound like millenials.

Some of the other reviews here mention the difficulty spikes and boss mechanics as negatives, but for me, the bosses were a fun challenge. They wildly change up the gameplay and force you to approach with care; you cannot stat-check the bosses by having one overpowered character. Instead, the fight mechanics require that you hit the boss from different sides and with different weapons to break through their defenses, and the whole experience does a great job of making you feel like you're a D&D party working together to take down a big monster.

As for negatives, there are certainly a few:
-Only about 40% of the dialogue is actually voiced, the less important scenes and side characters don't bother. Instead you just get single words, or grunts.
-The UI still needs work in a few areas, such as being able to hover over terms being used and see the definition rather than having to navigate to a different page to find it.
-The damage preview numbers aren't always accurate, since there is always a chance the enemy may block your attack. But that block % isn't shown anywhere, so you might think you have the perfect play, only to get denied by RNG that you couldn't account for or predict. RNG is part of the genre, but it would be nice to see these block% numbers so we know whether it's worth taking the risk.
-Stiff animations during transitional sequences and such. Mostly minor complaints.

The party members are already made, you just pick the 5 you like the most and go. Aside from picking male or female for the lead hero, there is no character creation here. This can be a pro or a con, depending on your preference. Some people like strong writing for defined characters (think Geralt of Rivia), while other people like making their own heroes from scratch. In this game though, you pick from the existing 10 and that's that.

Some games have core flaws that cannot really be fixed without overhauling the entire system, but thankfully, that isn't the case here. Most of this game's shortcomings can be easily fixed with a few layers of development paint and a bit more time.

Overall, an extremely solid strategy RPG effort, and easily worth grabbing for fans of the genre.

[h1] My review is from the perspective of someone who never played the first game and had not heard of this game until I saw the demo available on Steam. The review is half a defense of the game/attack on players leaving negative reviews and half actual useful information about the game. [/h1]

This game has me hooked. Played the demo, made it to Act II boss first run, and had to buy the game to see how that fight played out. Well, I got my ass handed to me and then it took a few runs to even get past the first boss again. And I loved it.

[h2] Now right off the bat, for those of you who can't read: [/h2]
"adapt to ever-shifting events, and grow stronger with every run."

This is a roguelite, you will start from level 0 after death, repeat the same core game play loop, face the same encounters, and you WILL die at a boss a number of times before you clear your first expedition. There ARE persistent upgrades, plenty of them. Power, armor, luck, shop upgrades, new skills, new relics, new systems, etc.

[b] DOWNLOAD THE DEMO FIRST. [/b] If you don't enjoy this core game play loop then do not buy the game. And if you can't read, you are going to have a bad time in this game. Read your skills, read the enemy skills, turn on threat range, play strategically, pay attention to the hints the game provides and revisit them in the guide if you need to. The number of reviews and discussions I have seen w/ players not understanding what this game is or how a system works (that was very clearly explained), and then rating it poorly is kind of absurd.

You WILL be frustrated by spell range, lack of AOE, bad rolls, etc.
You WILL experience encounters that you swear are unfair and you will complain about the game.

then...

You WILL have a break through in some form. Maybe it is a new Mythic ability, a new character unlock, a new synergy, a new relic, or maybe you finally pay attention to enemy abilities and threat range and play around that.
You WILL have a run where you are feeling great and steam rolling and you don't want to end. And you WILL get your ass kicked :)

ADAPT. GROW STRONGER.
If you are unwilling to adapt based on what the run is giving you and you throw in the towel after a few runs, then ggs, this isn't for you.

[h2] Level setting expectations for your first 10 runs or so: [/h2]

Through 30 hours (including 6 in the demo), I have gone on 7 expeditions and cleared Act III once. The first time I made it to Act III I was able to beat the boss. I don't expect to make it to Act III now every time just because I did it once.

That 30 hours was spent reading/listening to every bit of dialogue (save a few scenes from repeat encounters), reading skills + upgrades, inspecting characters before a turn to check on status effects, plan out enemy movement, interacting with every out of combat system, etc.I prefer to be thorough and understand a game and its systems and I try to ward off tiktok brain by letting the conversations play out naturally rather than skipping through them. I expect most players will get more than 7 runs in during their first 30 hours, but this is how I choose to play the game.

My first run was a fluke where a single character hard carried me through the first boss, leveled up a ton, and carried me to the Act II boss. Runs 2-5 had varied levels of success, but always progression. The run may have been shorter, but I got resources to purchase upgrades at the Altar of Fire or to unlock shop upgrades. I promoted my character's classes and changed up my party. These runs never felt bad to me.

Runs 6+7 I started to feel strong. Run 7 saw me hitting damage numbers 3x higher than in previous runs, exploring new play styles, and genuinely having a blast. I earned enough resources in this run to promote 5 character's classes and take my altar to level 7. There is still SO much to unlock and I'm expecting mixed results from my next 3 runs as I experiment with two more new characters and different play styles.


[h2] Story, Art, Voice Acting [/h2]
You will uncover bits of the story with each run, specifically after dying a couple of times and then your first boss victories. You also earn currency that unlocks memories that play out as little scenes from your past. Leveling up your relationships between characters also unlocks dialogue and you will spend a decent amount of time reading/clearing these conversations from The Lodge. I can't say that I was immediately drawn in by the story, but that probably had more to do with the fact that I was playing the demo to see if I enjoyed the game and didn't want to spend the mental energy to get into another story that I may not stick with. As the game has gone on and the story unfolds, I am finding myself a little more interested in it. I can at least give you a summary of major events and key characters and I'm not skipping dialogue, but the story isn't a major concern of mine.

I will say that it is a bit odd to be going on these expeditions with your party, have bonding moments during the run, advance your relationship, and then the conversations you unlock afterwards seem to walk the relationship back. I always check for new convos after every run and they feel slightly out of order or inconsistent/misplaced for where I am at in the story.

I really enjoy the art style, the voice acting is pretty good (I am playing as the female main character), and the combat animations are good enough for me. I'm not very particular about any of these as the combat and core game play are what I am most interested in, but it is an added bonus that I enjoy them. There are some parts of the game without any voice lines and bits and pieces where what is spoken doesn't exactly match the text, but nothing major.


[h2] TLDR [/h2]
100% recommend if you are into turn based tactical game play WITHIN A ROGUELITE. Combat, tactics, upgrades are all great IMO. There is enough story and out of combat content to keep things progressing along and break up the runs, but you can skip through dialogue if you'd like.

This is an interesting roguelite that does things pretty well for the most part.  Each run consists of you moving through 3-4 zones (depending on your progress through the story) with encounters in each zone, those encounters being either fights or various events (some of which involve random dice rolls).  Fights can have various objectives or conditions (protect some villagers, poison mist slowly creeping across the map etc) but most of the time just killing all enemies will achieve the objective.  Run progression involves getting random skills on level up for your characters as well as upgrading their equipment which gives both passive and active skills.

There is a decent amount of meta progression and unlocks, including getting new party members, improving the merchant you encounter in runs, unlocking new relics and artifacts etc.  The main character's personal story is decent and you do get additional lore and story tidbits here and there even after beating the main bosss.  I'd say the one issue with this game is that runs tend to be quite long, several hours (there's even an achievement for doing a full run in less than 5 hours although that wasn't really hard to get but it gives you an idea of how long they can be).  Given that in order to max out things like relationships between your party members or unlocking various side endings requires multiple runs this really makes you feel the run lengths as time goes on.

That said, the game is solid, it's done a good job of blending TTRPG and roguelite and I've enjoyed my time with it so far although I doubt I'll try and 100% the game simply due to having to do a lot more runs.

tldr; This is a full letter grade improvement over previous title and worth your time if you enjoy turn-based strategy.


Gameplay itself showcased the strongest improvement overall; we have evolved past a shallow fire emblem clone into becoming its own unique experience. Classes now process their own identities and have different builds to explore. Skills have bombastic presentation and passives augment play style rather than just increase stats.

The roguelike aspect is fairly solid. You feel progression with each attempt, experience different possible outcomes, and there are enough game changers to throw you off. 

The downsides I see are map enviroments and length of each run, the negative aspects of each amplifying one another. Battle maps are boring, flat, and will be the same layout depending on the battle encounter. Runs can be between 2 - 3 1/2 hours, so you can get burnt out in an extend play sessions with a sense of deja-vu. 

The story and characters were the blemishes on the previous entry. It encompassed such a large portion of the experience that its mediocrity blackened out the positives. I think they are finding their strides now and realized their limitations to make a better narrative experience. These characters have more depth and while not amazing, are leagues better than the blandness we had before. While the story is limited by the nature of being a roguelike, I think it was acceptable and well-paced.  Voice direction was on point this time around and also showed a massive spike in improvement.

While the visuals have experienced a downgrade, I think it is a better presentation and has style that is enjoyable. The awkward cutscenes and horrendous facial animations are thankfully gone in favor of portraits and visual novel dialogue scenes.

The game itself is a very solid turn-based strategy roguelike, with a couple of flaws around the metaprogression. 

Combat is a streamlined version of the dev's first game: Lost Eidolons (which is also worth a pickup!) and a little on the easier side due to how broken each playable character can get with various upgrades. However a low based difficulty is fixed by a heat/trial system which seems like it will get new and more challenging buffs for enemies. But it's still satisfying to put together and use these broken kits, and it never gets so easy that you can just brain-off a map.

The main metaprogression is a little shallow. You obtain currency each run to upgrade the altar of flames, but the upgrades are pretty insiginificant stat upgrades with a couple of actually impactful ones here and there. Devs have mentioned changing it but that was quite a few patches ago so I think it's here to stay.

As for story and characters, I think they've done a really good job of continuing on the world they built in their previous game, without totally tying themselves to the original cast of characters. And it's all told to the player by a very great cast of VA's that are a relatively new addition. I want to learn more about the characters and want to listen to them talk.

All in all I recommend the game as-is as far as mechanics and design go, and am excited to see the story completed in the release version.

Overall, Veil of the Witch is a very good game and a worthy continuation of the series.

I play A LOT of turn-based games, and this is just so bare bones. If this game was made by a single dev, I might not be so harsh...but it's from a studio.

Units do not have engagement, so there are no attacks of opportunity no matter how many enemies run right past your front line units. This means that you cannot limit movement of enemy units with positioning. You cannot have tank units control the battlefield at all. Enemies run around anywhere they want almost any time they want. Because there are ZERO penalties for running right past your units, the enemy always gangs up on single units at a time, killing them quickly.

So far...zero Area of Effect (AOE) attacks or spells. Your gigantic ax or massive two-handed sword can hit exactly ONE enemy per turn. No sweeps. No spins. Your fireball spell affects ONE enemy. Your lightning bolt hits ONE enemy...no lining up shots to punish the enemy in groups. My big crushing special attack with my main character does exactly 2 points more damage than a normal attack...so basically 38 points of damage versus WHOA 40. 

Bows are virtually useless. They have a range of fire that is only one single square beyond a unit using a spear, so their range is basically 10 feet or so....TOTAL. Spells are equally short ranged. What game has bows limited to a range of 10 feet?

Maps are so BORING. Very little variation. No differences in elevation. Some water. Some poison clouds. Otherwise, you are fighting on a big open map with maybe a rock formation or two.

WAY too much talking! It seems like half of the game is clicking through boring conversations just so you can do something other than listen to some dumb tale for 10-20 minutes real time.

The voice actor for the main character (played as a male) is not the guy for this job. He sounds totally out of place, like some hipster slinging pick-up lines in a nightclub...not a warrior and champion who deals death to his foes. This may seem like a petty issue, but you have to listen to SO MUCH TALKING that it eventually starts to grate. I think that the appropriate description here is "smarmy," and that is not a term I bust out often.

PROS:
- The characters are in line with the original series. They're not very complicated, but likeable.
- The combat is mostly an improvement to the original, but with a few hiccups.
- I like some of the new trinkets.
- The missions are mostly pleasant, although small scale versions of the original.

CONS:
- The repetitive, rogue-like structure of the game is not satisfying. I recommend Hades instead.
- The game is meant to be failed, like most other rogue-likes, but this game fails to realise that the charm of rogue-likes is that you get to develop your characters, strengthen them, meet familiar characters with new dialogue and build a better HQ like in Darkest Dungeon. 
- There is very little improvement for each new round of failure. It's a steady grind. I like grinds, but this is way too much gameplay for too little of a reward. Playing Tetris on repeat at least gives you the goal of beating your own score. This game doesn't even do that.
- They completely removed many features of the original game, which is what made Lost Eidolons great to begin with, like a character system with building relationships, and training for classes and improving armour. These systems are already made. I don't know why they couldn't just have implemented them into the game.

The only reason to buy this game is to support the studio so they can make a Lost Eidolons 2.

This game is awful. I wanted to give it a shot because I normally love turn-based RPGs, but now I really regret not refunding, even though I got it on sale.

I play A LOT of turn-based games, and this is just so bare bones. If this game was made by a single dev, I might not be so harsh...but it's from a studio.

Units do not have engagement, so there are no attacks of opportunity no matter how many enemies run right past your front line units. This means that you cannot limit movement of enemy units with positioning. You cannot have tank units control the battlefield at all. Enemies run around anywhere they want almost any time they want. Because there are ZERO penalties for running right past your units, the enemy always gangs up on single units at a time, killing them quickly.

So far...zero Area of Effect (AOE) attacks or spells. Your gigantic ax or massive two-handed sword can hit exactly ONE enemy per turn. No sweeps. No spins. Your fireball spell affects ONE enemy. Your lightning bolt hits ONE enemy...no lining up shots to punish the enemy in groups. My big crushing special attack with my main character does exactly 2 points more damage than a normal attack...so basically 38 points of damage versus WHOA 40. 

Bows are virtually useless. They have a range of fire that is only one single square beyond a unit using a spear, so their range is basically 10 feet or so....TOTAL. Spells are equally short ranged. What game has bows limited to a range of 10 feet?

Maps are so BORING. Very little variation. No differences in elevation. Some water. Some poison clouds. Otherwise, you are fighting on a big open map with maybe a rock formation or two.

WAY too much talking! It seems like half of the game is clicking through boring conversations just so you can do something other than listen to some dumb tale for 10-20 minutes real time.

The voice actor for the main character (played as a male) is not the guy for this job. He sounds totally out of place, like some hipster slinging pick-up lines in a nightclub...not a warrior and champion who deals death to his foes. This may seem like a petty issue, but you have to listen to SO MUCH TALKING that it eventually starts to grate. I think that the appropriate description here is "smarmy," and that is not a term I bust out often.

The nail in the coffin is the fact that everything is stacked against you in the first boss battle. They make you grind and grind to get enough permanent upgrades to advance. There is no way to progress without grinding, no matter how well you play. They FORCE the grind on you and you absolutely cannot win until you grind out the upgrades you need to advance. I just keep asking myself, "Why am I doing this rather than doing something I actually enjoy?"
